name: clintonia-borealis
country-or-region-of-origin: Eastern North America, Newfoundland south to the Appalachians.
distribution: South to North Carolina and Georgia
wildlife-value: Songbirds and chipmunks eat the berries.
edibility: Young leaves are chopped and added to salads, or boiled for 10 minutes and served with butter and seasonings.  Sour flavor.
light: Dappled Sunlight (Shade through upper canopy all day)
Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: The fruit is a bright, light to dark blue berry that is poisonous.
flower-description: Terminal raceme of small 4 to 8 yellow to greenish-yellow, bell-like flowers that nod on a tall leafless stalk. It is 6-parted, has three petals and three sepals, and flowers in a terminal cluster.
leaf-description: Two to four basal, shiny, bright green, oblong leaves and 3 to 5 strap-like leaves. The leaves are 4 to 10 inches long, edible, somewhat leathery, and have hairy-fringed margins.
poison-symptoms: This plant CAUSES ONLY LOW TOXICITY IF EATEN. No cases are known. Poisonous through ingestion. Poisonous parts are suspected to be the berries.
poison-toxic-principle: Unknown; suspected since related to toxic plants
